entry.title: Hedonic Pricing: What Do Investors Pay For?
entry.content:
Executive summary
Investors do not primarily pay for short-term margin spikes or isolated growth initiatives.  Instead, over a 35-year horizon, the market has consistently rewarded one thing above all else: persistency.  This is the term Goldman Sachs attaches to the capital structure discipline, specifically leverage (Assets/Equity).  We find that leverage explains the majority of the variation in Home Depot’s Market Cap / Equity, our proxy for the Price/Book ratio.  This finding closely replicates Goldman Sachs’ famous analysis of what markets pay for, but applies to a single company and validates using long-horizon time-series data. Profitability and efficiency matter — but they come second.

This note describes our findings in three simple blocks:

  • data preparation and transformation
  • results and interpretation
  • what it means for Home Depot and investors.

 

1. Data preparation: looking at Home Depot the way markets do

This analysis starts from a simple premise:

If we want to understand how investors value Home Depot, we must model Home Depot the way investors observe it.

We assembled 144 quarters (1990–2025 YTD) of data covering both market valuation metrics (P/B ratio, Market Cap, Enterprise Value) and accounting fundamentals (assets, equity, leverage, margins, asset turnover).

This is important: unlike cross-sectional studies across many firms, this model is time-series for a single company. We are not asking why Home Depot is valued differently than Lowe’s.  We are asking a more precise question:

What has historically driven changes in Home Depot’s valuation over time?

Log transformations: elasticity, not levels

All core variables are expressed in logarithmic form. This is essential for interpretation:

  • Coefficients become elasticities
  • Relationships become scale-free
  • Long-term growth dynamics dominate short-term noise

In plain English: we are modeling percentage changes investors respond to, not absolute dollar movements.

The dependent (predicted) variable is the

ln(Market Cap / Equity), a proxy for the P/B ratio, directly links market valuation to balance-sheet fundamentals — exactly how long-term equity investors think.

Three independent (predictor) variables are

Leverage = (Assets - Goodwill) / Stockholders Equity where we specifically remove Goodwill to account for “tangible leverage” only,

Net Margin = Net Income / Revenue, 

Turnover = Revenue / (Assets - Goodwill) here too, assets are net of goodwill for "tangible turnover."

In one quarter, Home Depot reported negative net income. In 9 quarters the company reported negative equity - initially in 2019 as a result of the adoption of the FASB ASU No. 2016-02, "Leases (Topic 842)".  This is why the lines in the plot below exhibit discontinuities: natural logarithm of a negative number is undefined.

In log terms, valuation and operating fundamentals move in clear and persistent co-movement over time.  Sustained multiple expansion coincides with rising operating efficiency, greater leverage capacity, and improving margins, while periods of valuation compression align with broad-based fundamental deterioration.  Valuation itself behaves as a slow-moving state variable, reflecting investors’ long-run assessment of economic capacity, whereas operating metrics adjust at higher frequency around that state.  Even during externally imposed disruptions—such as recessions and market panics—temporary dislocations give way to re-convergence, underscoring that market multiples are ultimately disciplined by fundamentals rather than driven by sentiment alone.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This systematic co-movement directly motivates a hedonic valuation, in which observed market multiples are modeled as the equilibrium price investors assign to distinct operating characteristics rather than as standalone time-series outcomes.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

 

2. The hedonic pricing regression: what explains Home Depot's valuation?

Conceptually, the model mirrors the DuPont identity, which decomposes Return on Equity into three elements:

  • Leverage (Assets / Equity)
  • Profitability (Net Margin)
  • Efficiency (Asset Turnover)

Our model - with the log-transformed data - is:

To accommodate periods of negative net margin and negative stockholders’ equity, we introduced dummy variables that flag sign changes (0 for positive values, 1 for negative).  The inclusion of dummy variables allows the model to accommodate sign changes without materially altering coefficient magnitudes or inference. 

The regression, run in R Studio, produced a formula where most coefficients are statistically significant at the 5% level (p<0.05).  The ln_net_margin variable returned a p-value of 0.0744, indicating a 7.4% probability of observing this result (or one more extreme) if there were actually no relationship between ln_net_margin and ln_mktcap_over_equity.

We drop the decimals:

Here is the most intuitive interpretation of the model’s coefficients and log-terms: elasticity. These bars represent standardized coefficients, not raw elasticities, and are intended for relative magnitude and intuition, not literal percentage translation.


 

Home Depot’s valuation is most sensitive to changes in asset turnover, indicating that improvements in capital efficiency drive market multiples more powerfully than margin expansion alone.

In raw log terms, leverage can be interpreted as follows: a 1% increase in leverage increases Market Cap / Equity by approximately 1%.

Net margins exhibit a comparatively modest elasticity, suggesting that accounting profitability, while important, does not independently command valuation premiums.

Taken together, the results align closely with how long-term equity investors think: sustainable valuation expansion is rooted in efficient deployment of capital, not short-term margin optimization.

 

The key result: persistency dominates

The model has R2 of 94.05% and Adjusted R2 of 93.91%.  If we decompose the individual predictors’ contribution to this explained variance in Market Cap/Equity, the key conclusion emerges:

Visually, this is striking: the largest block by far is leverage. Most of what investors paid for Home Depot over 35 years is captured by three variables of which Leverage is the most significant. This is what Goldman Sachs found in their panel data analysis calling the hedonic pricing element persistency.

Persistency, in Goldman’s framework, means:

  • Stable capital structure
  • Predictable balance-sheet scaling
  • Consistency in how equity is multiplied into assets and cash flows

What we have done here is replicate that insight, but:

  • For one company
  • Using 35 years of quarterly data
  • With a fully transparent regression framework

The alignment is almost exact.

Notably, the model contains no explicit time trends, macroeconomic variables, or sentiment indicators—yet it explains over 94% of valuation variation, underscoring how consistently markets price the same economic fundamentals.

In Home Depot’s case, leverage alone explains roughly two-thirds of the market’s valuation signal. Profitability matters — but it is secondary, less persistent, and less trusted by investors as a long-term signal.

Both actual and predicted series represent the log market-cap-to-equity multiple where

The chart shows that a simple three-variable hedonic model tracks Home Depot’s valuation remarkably well over more than three decades. Even though the model has no awareness of time, cycles, or sentiment, its predicted valuation closely follows the actual market valuation across multiple regimes. Deviations between the two lines are concentrated in periods of market stress or speculative excess, while long-run trends are captured cleanly.

In other words, investors consistently price the same economic fundamentals, though they might temporarily lose discipline during panics and recessions.

This directly supports the executive intuition captured in the quote by Dilip Shanghvi, the founder and CEO of Sun Pharmaceuticals:

“I will never risk capital; but I will risk profit.”

Markets agree.

 

3. How solid is our model? Is it "too clean"?

No serious business model should avoid this question.

Residual behavior (what we checked)

We explicitly reviewed:

  • Residual distribution
  • Residuals vs. fitted values
  • Time clustering during stress periods

 

 


 


 

With F-statistics 684.4 on 3 and 130 degrees of freedom and p-value < 2.2 x 10-16, the model is structurally sound, though markets still panic occasionally — and then revert.

That is exactly what we would expect from real investors.

What do residuals tell us

Residuals widen during periods of macro-financial stress, including the Global Financial Crisis, COVID, and the post-2022 rate shock. This is expected: markets temporarily price fear, liquidity constraints, and narrative risk beyond firm-level fundamentals.

Outside stress regimes, residuals oscillate tightly around zero with no persistent bias. Deviations cluster in time rather than by sign, indicating regime effects rather than model misspecification. Overvaluation episodes—most notably the late 1990s—mean-revert as market discipline reasserts itself.

Bottom line: the model “fails” when markets panic — and reliably re-anchors valuation once sentiment normalizes.

 

*   *   *

 

So, what does this actually mean for Home Depot?

Insight #1: capital discipline is the valuation anchor

Home Depot’s high valuation multiple is not fragile.  It is anchored in:

  • Consistent leverage
  • Predictable scaling of equity
  • Transparent capital return policy

Any unexpected shift in capital structure — aggressive deleveraging or sudden debt expansion — would matter far more to valuation than a bad margin quarter.

Insight #2: profitability matters — but only if it is repeatable

Operational improvements (margin, turnover, ROA) explain about one quarter of valuation variation.  That is meaningful — but markets discount one-off wins.  Investors prefer:

  • Incremental improvements
  • Predictable execution
  • Fewer surprises

Spectacular quarters impress analysts. Consistent ones move valuation.

Insight #3: macro matters less than headlines suggest

Despite constant focus on rates, housing cycles, and sentiment, macro variables explain only a single-digit share of long-term valuation variation.  Home Depot’s valuation history is fundamentally a company-driven story, not a macro-driven one.

Once full-year 2025 financials are available, we will:

  • Re-estimate the model
  • Test coefficient stability
  • Re-evaluate valuation implications under the new regime and compare/contrast the hedonic pricing model with the traditional DCF valuation model

If history is any guide, the conclusion is unlikely to change — but the path may.

 

Final thought

Markets are often accused of being short-term and irrational. Over 35 years of Home Depot data suggests the opposite.

Investors are remarkably consistent in what they reward.

They pay for persistency.
